summary_points.title: Six-Day Winning Streak Snapped Amid Powell’s Speech
summary_points.summary: The Indian stock market snapped its six-day winning run on Friday as indices fell sharply ahead of Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s Jackson Hole address, with the Nifty 50 losing 213.65 points to close at 24,870.10 and the Sensex down 693.86 points to 81,306.85. Hints of a potential Fed rate reduction spurred panic selling, overshadowing weekly gains and setting the tone for cautious trading.

summary_points.title: Technical Outlook: Key Levels for Sensex and Nifty
summary_points.summary: Technical analysts highlight the 50-day simple moving average (SMA) at 81,900 for the Sensex as a pivotal level; failure to hold this support could drag the index toward the 20-day SMA near 81,000–81,100 or even 80,400. On the upside, sustained trading above 81,900 may trigger a fresh rally toward resistance zones at 82,500 and 83,300, guiding short-term trading strategies.

summary_points.title: Auto Stocks Bolster Markets, Paints and Conglomerates Lag
summary_points.summary: Amid broader market weakness, auto heavyweights such as M&M, Maruti, and Bharat Electronics (BEL) emerged as top performers on the Nifty 50, while large-cap names like Grasim, Asian Paints, and Adani Enterprises faced heavy selling pressure. This divergence underscores sector rotation and profit-taking ahead of key global policy announcements.

summary_points.title: FPI Selling Sparks Next Week’s Market Triggers
summary_points.summary: Foreign portfolio investors’ cautious stance and offloading ahead of global rate cues emerge as a prime catalyst, alongside expectations of a US Fed rate cut in September, mixed corporate earnings, valuation pressures, domestic policy reforms such as GST changes, and technical factors. These five potential triggers are set to shape Indian market moves in the upcoming week.

summary_points.title: MarketSmith’s Top Stock Recommendations
summary_points.summary: MarketSmith India’s August 25 recommendations spotlight stocks demonstrating strong base formations and relative strength, aiming to capitalize on post-correction resilience. These picks follow a week where Nifty fell 0.85% to 24,870 amid profit booking in heavyweight sectors, while broader indices ended with weekly gains driven by domestic institutional (DII) buying and hopes for GST reforms.

summary_points.title: Global Cues Point to Higher Monday Open
summary_points.summary: Domestic benchmark indices are poised for a higher start on Monday, tracking robust Asian and US markets and a near-90% probability of a Fed rate cut priced in by traders. Futures on Gift Nifty traded at a premium of around 55 points, signaling optimism after Powell’s Jackson Hole remarks hinted at more dovish policy ahead.

articles.snippet: In the near term, particularly on Tuesday, the Indian market may trade sideways as traders await the final verdict on Trump’s additional 25% tariff decision on 27th August. top_performing_sectors.explanation: Auto stocks like M&M and Maruti led the Nifty outperformers as investors rotated into high-quality cyclicals ahead of Powell’s Jackson Hole speech.
Telecom shares saw strong buying interest as participants sought defensive exposure amid volatile global cues.
Healthcare stocks attracted demand as investors looked for defensive plays during the market pullback.

underperforming_sectors.explanation: Banking heavyweight stocks faced profit booking pressure, dragging the financial sector lower.
Metals shares came under selling pressure on weak global cues and FII outflows.
Material stocks, including names like Grasim and Asian Paints, weakened amid broad-based market decline.

losers.reason: Slumped on profit-taking and weak global cues before Powell’s remarks.

market_drivers.summary: Indian markets opened on a buoyant note as GIFT Nifty traded at a healthy premium, driven by positive global cues from Asian peers and Wall Street after Fed Chair Jerome Powell’s Jackson Hole remarks stoked rate-cut expectations. Domestically, sustained DII buying and optimism around potential GST reforms underpinned the market, even as profit-booking weighed on heavyweight banking and metal stocks. Corporate highlights such as Apollo Micro Systems’ Rs 1.1 bn avionic export order and a steady rupee—alongside softer gold and silver prices—further shaped the mixed but overall resilient trading session.
